titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp Collection: Seton Hall University Law School Center for Policy and Research Records TAM.472
titlestmt.author: Daniel Michelson, 2011

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 14:28:00 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp Collection: Seton Hall University Law School Center for Policy and Research Records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Seton Hall University. Center for Policy and Research

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Mark Denebeaux on behalf of Seton Hall Univiersity's Center for Policy and Research; additional materials were donated in 2010. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2009.014, 2010.069, and 2010.078.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series:
Series II: Death in Camp Delta Files, 2002-2010
Series I is arranged chronologically and Series II is arranged alphabetically.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Seton Hall University Law School's Center for Policy and Research is led by Professor Mark P. Denbeaux and focuses on the issues of "Interrogations & Intelligence, National Security, and Forensics." Denbeaux's work for Guantanamo detainees led him to lead the production of a series of reports on Guantanamo that have become the Center's most well known initiative.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection was donated to the Tamiment Library by Mark P. Denbeaux on behalf of the Center for Policy and Research in three installments from 2009-2010. The archived website was migrated from the California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service to the Internet Archive's Archive-It Service in November 2015. The link to California Digital Library was removed in October 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp Collection: Dorsey and Whitney, LLP Records (TAM 509)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Collection is part of a joint project involving Seton Hall University Law School's Center for Policy and Research (Donor), and the Tamiment Library to document the legal and public policy issues related to the administration of the Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility by the United States Department of Defense.
Currently the collection consists of two series.

Series I: Guantanamo Reports, 2006-2009 contains paper copies of X of the reports on Guantanamo published by the Center for Policy and Research. These reports have examined Guantanamo through analyzing Department of Defense data. Most of the reports can be downloaded from the Center for Policy and Research's website at http://law.shu.edu/ProgramsCenters/PublicIntGovServ/policyresearch/Guantanamo-Reports.cfm

Series II: Death in Camp Delta Files, 2002-2010 is made up of U. S. Government documents about the deaths of three detainees obtained by their lawyers and subsequently used in the Center for Policy and Research's report Death in Camp Delta.
Additional materials will be added to the collection over time.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyright is assumed to be held by the original creator of individual items in the collection; these items are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Mark Denbeaux and Seton Hall Univerisity's Center for Policy and Research were transferred to New York University in 2009 by Mark Denbeaux. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.

did.unittitle: Series II: Death in Camp Delta Files

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Shortly after midnight on June 10, 2006, Yasser Talal al Zahrani (Detainee ISN 93), Mani Shaman Turki al-Habardi Al-Utaybi (Detainee ISN 588), and Ali Abdullah Ahmed (Detainee ISN 693) died in custody at the Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp. According to the U.S. Government, the detainees hung themselves in their cells in the first successful suicide at the camp. However, critics have disputed this account, maintaining that the detainees were accidentally killed during a brutal interrogation.
NOTE: Many different versions of the detainees' names can be found, particularly for Detainee ISN 588. Even a single document often has multiple versions of the name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of scans of over 7,500 pages of government documents obtained by lawyers for two of the prisoners about their death and the subsequent government investigations. These include medical records, reports on detainees, interrogation reports, and investigation files. Many of the documents have been heavily redacted.

The bulk of the material was used in the Center for Policy and Research's report Death in Camp Delta, which heavily criticizes the investigation as flawed and the product of a coverup. The report can be found at http://law.shu.edu/ProgramsCenters/PublicIntGovServ/policyresearch/Guantanamo-Reports.cfm

Subseries II:A: Dickstein Shapiro Responsives contains government documents obtained by David Engelhardt and Reginald McKnight of Dickstein Shapiro who represented Ali Abdullah Ahmed (Detainee ISN 693), a 37 year old Yemeni national.

Subseries II:B: Jeff Davis Files includes government documents obtained by Jeff Davis of Moore & Van Allen and George Daly who represented Mani Shaman Turki al-Habardi Al-Utaybi (Detainee ISN 588), a 30 year old Saudi national.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is arranged into two subseries:

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Some of the documents in this series can also be found on the Department of Defense website at http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/operation_and_plans/Detainee/OtherDetaineeRelatedDocuments.html

Series III: Archived Website

dao.xlink:title: Seton Hall Law School - Guantanamo Reports

daodesc.p: Seton Hall Law School - Guantanamo Reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Since 2006, Fellows with the Center for Policy and Research have been analyzing government data to illuminate the interrogations and intelligence practices of the United States. The findings have been quite revealing, showing that what's found in the data is often the best divulger of the truth. The reports have been introduced into the Congressional record by the Senate Armed Services Committee, the Senate Judiciary Committee, the House Armed Services Committee, and as part of a Resolution by the European Parliament. The website contains reports from Series I and additional reports published after 2009.
